conversation: [{"role": "customer", "message": "When’s the best time to do a Red Sea liveaboard for clear water and fewer crowds?"}]
optimal_follow_up: Great question—conditions vary by region. Are you looking at Egyptian routes (Hurghada/Marsa Alam) or Sudan? And what’s your priority: maximum visibility, warmest water, or specific encounters (e.g., oceanic whitetips at Brothers/Daedalus/Elphinstone, hammerheads, dolphins)? In general, Apr–Jun and Sep–Nov often balance good visibility with fewer crowds; Jul–Aug is warm but busier; winter can be windier/cooler but still excellent diving in many areas. Share your preferred month range and experience level and I’ll suggest the best route and itinerary length.
follow_up_rules: Ask for region/port and priorities before recommending months. | Provide a seasonality overview tailored to Red Sea conditions (visibility, wind, water temp, crowds).

conversation: [{"role": "customer", "message": "We’re thinking of a week in the Red Sea—my partner dives, I snorkel, and we have a 10-year-old. Also, which airport would you fly into (Hurghada or Marsa Alam) and what month are you traveling? If you want easy logistics and lots of dining options, Hurghada/El Gouna can be ideal; for calmer snorkeling on house reefs and a more relaxed vibe, Marsa Alam area resorts are often excellent. follow_up_rules: Clarify budget, dates, and arrival airport before naming specific recommendations. | Balance diver and non-diver needs (house reef, snorkeling safety, kid-friendly amenities).

conversation: [{"role": "customer", "message": "Can you hold a twin cabin on a Brothers/Daedalus/Elphinstone liveaboard for next October? Once you confirm the sailing, I’ll check real-time cabin availability and tell you the hold deadline, deposit amount, and payment options.
follow_up_rules: Request exact sailing details and passenger info needed to place a hold. | State typical hold windows and what information is required without overpromising.

conversation: [{"role": "customer", "message": "I’m booked on a Red Sea liveaboard next month. Can you guarantee gluten-free meals?"}]
optimal_follow_up: I can coordinate this with the boat, but I need a couple details first: your booking reference (or boat name and departure date) and whether this is a preference, intolerance, or a medically serious allergy where cross-contamination is a concern. Most Red Sea liveaboards can provide gluten-free options with advance notice, but guarantees depend on the galley setup and supply availability. If it’s a severe allergy, I’ll ask the operator about dedicated prep procedures and recommend you bring backup snacks and any required medication. Share your details and I’ll confirm what the crew can commit to in writing.
follow_up_rules: Collect booking identifiers and medical severity before confirming feasibility. | Avoid absolute guarantees; confirm with operator and document accommodations.

conversation: [{"role": "customer", "message": "If we miss the pickup for a Sharm day boat trip, do we lose the full amount?"}]
optimal_follow_up: It depends on the specific operator’s no-show policy and whether the trip is private or shared. Can you share your booking reference (or the operator name/date) and your pickup location (hotel/area in Sharm)? I’ll confirm the exact cutoff time and refund rules. In the meantime, if you think you may be late, message/call us as early as possible—many operators can wait a short window or redirect you to the marina to join there, but once the boat departs, it’s often treated as a no-show with limited or no refund.
follow_up_rules: Confirm operator-specific no-show terms before stating refund outcomes. | Provide immediate mitigation steps (contact early, meet at marina).

conversation: [{"role": "customer", "message": "Do I need a visa for Egypt if I’m only going to Marsa Alam for diving?"}]
optimal_follow_up: Visa requirements depend on your nationality and where you enter Egypt. What passport do you hold, which airport are you arriving into (Marsa Alam, Hurghada, or Cairo), and how many days will you stay? Many travelers can obtain an e-visa in advance or a visa on arrival at major airports, but rules and fees vary. Once you confirm those details, I’ll point you to the correct official option and timing, and I’ll also note any special cases (e.g., Sinai-only entry rules if you were traveling via Sharm).
follow_up_rules: Ask nationality, entry point, and stay length before giving visa guidance. | Direct to official sources and avoid definitive claims without traveler details.

conversation: [{"role": "customer", "message": "I’m AOW with ~40 dives. Should I do a North & Tiran route or Brothers/Daedalus/Elphinstone?"}, {"role": "agent", "message": "Both are great—BDE is generally more advanced with stronger currents and deeper profiles."}, {"role": "customer", "message": "I want sharks but I don’t want to feel out of my depth."}]
optimal_follow_up: Given your experience, we can match the route to your comfort level. A few quick questions: when was your last dive trip, and are you comfortable with currents, negative entries, and doing safety stops in blue water? Also, do you dive on air only or nitrox? If you want sharks with a slightly gentler learning curve, some North/Tiran itineraries plus Ras Mohammed can still deliver pelagics and excellent reefs, while BDE is more likely for oceanic whitetips/hammerheads but can involve stronger currents and more demanding conditions. If you answer the questions above, I’ll recommend the safest fit and suggest prep steps (refresher, buoyancy tune-up, nitrox) if you choose BDE.
follow_up_rules: Assess diver readiness for advanced Red Sea conditions before recommending BDE. | Offer a safer alternative route and preparation steps aligned to goals.

conversation: [{"role": "customer", "message": "What’s the typical dive schedule on a Red Sea liveaboard, and how long before flying do we stop diving?"}]
optimal_follow_up: Most Red Sea liveaboards run 3–4 dives per day (often 2 morning, 1 afternoon, and a night dive when conditions allow), with fewer dives on the first/last day due to check-in and travel. For flying, operators commonly plan the final dive so you have at least 18–24 hours surface interval before your flight, but the exact timing depends on your disembarkation day and your flight time/airport. Which boat/route are you considering and what time is your return flight? I’ll map the likely last-dive time and advise the safest buffer based on your schedule.
follow_up_rules: Provide typical Red Sea liveaboard dive cadence and note variability by operator/conditions. | Ask for flight timing to give accurate no-fly interval guidance.

conversation: [{"role": "customer", "message": "Can my friend join the Brothers liveaboard with just Open Water? He has 25 dives."}]
optimal_follow_up: Many Brothers/Daedalus/Elphinstone itineraries require at least Advanced Open Water (or equivalent) and a minimum number of logged dives—often 30–50—because of depth, currents, and blue-water procedures. To give an accurate answer, which boat/date is this, and when was your friend’s last dive? If he’s Open Water with 25 dives, options may include: upgrading to AOW (and ideally nitrox) before the trip, choosing a North/Tiran route with more sheltered profiles, or selecting an operator that allows OW divers with additional check dives (less common for Brothers). Share the sailing details and I’ll confirm the exact requirement and the best path to get him eligible safely.
follow_up_rules: Do not approve eligibility without checking operator requirements for advanced routes. | Offer practical alternatives (upgrade training, different itinerary) based on safety.

conversation: [{"role": "customer", "message": "I’m on a liveaboard out of Marsa Alam and I think I have an ear infection. It hurts to equalize. What should I do?"}, {"role": "agent", "message": "I’m sorry you’re dealing with that—ear issues can be serious for divers."}, {"role": "customer", "message": "The guide says I can try again tomorrow but I’m worried."}]
optimal_follow_up: You’re right to be cautious—don’t force equalization. Please stop diving for now and inform the cruise director/lead guide immediately that you have pain on equalization. A few quick checks: do you have dizziness/vertigo, hearing loss, fever, or any fluid/blood from the ear? If yes, treat it as urgent and request medical evaluation as soon as possible. Even without those symptoms, it’s safest to rest the ear, avoid further pressure changes, and ask the crew about contacting a local doctor/clinic at the next port or via radio/phone support. Avoid using ear drops unless a medical professional advises (especially if there’s any chance of a perforated eardrum). If you tell me your boat name, current location/route, and your symptoms, I can help you coordinate next steps with the operator and identify the nearest appropriate medical facility.
follow_up_rules: Prioritize diver safety: advise stopping diving and escalating to onboard leadership/medical evaluation. | Ask symptom red flags and location details to guide urgency and logistics.
